example: She made out a shopping list for the weekly groceries. [j33] Who should I make the cheque out to? [j33] Could you make me out a receipt, please? '   (b) '[cf2] If you make something out, you manage to see, hear or understand it, usually with difficulty.  [cf2]I could just make out two headlights through the fog. [j33] It was too noisy to make out what they were saying. [j33] I couldn't make out what point she was trying to convey. '   (c) '[cf2] If you make out that something is the case, you claim or give the impression that it's true.  [cf2]He's not as clever as people make him out to be. [j33] Anna makes out she's such an expert and she's not, you know

If you make something up, you prepare or construct it.  [cf2]This prescription will have to be made up at the pharmacy. [j33] She made up a costume from some old scraps of material. [j33] The furniture comes packed flat[j4]you have to make it up yourself. '   (c) '[cf2] If you make up a story or excuse, you invent it.  It is not true.  [cf2]I don't want to see her[j4]tell her I'm not at home or make up some other excuse. [j33] Verena makes up wonderful stories to entertain the children. '   (d) '[cf2] When different things are part of a whole, they make up that whole.  They form it.  [cf2]Eleven players make up a cricket team. [j33] A galaxy is made up of thousands of stars. '   (e) '[cf2] If you make up with someone, you become friends again after you have a quarrel or disagreement with them.  [cf2]Father and son finally ~made up after a five year separation.  23 ' make up for'  '[cf2] If something makes up for something else, it is something good that makes the bad thing seem less unfortunate. example: On a clear night, you can see myriads of stars in the sky

senses.definition: ' You can use myself to emphasise that it is you who does something.
example: I surprised myself by doing better than I expected. [j33] I thought to myself how lucky I was
I'm sure she got the message[j4]I gave it to her myself. ~[j33] I don't blame you for being surprised[j4]I can hardly believe it myself

senses.definition: ' If someone is being mysterious, they hint that they know more about something than they're revealing.
example: A mysterious object was seen in the sky. [j33] No-one could explain the mysterious events that took place that night. [j33] He's a bit of a mysterious character
Don't be mysterious[j4]tell us who it is

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]m[j11]stri, -t[j17]ri'    A mystery is something whose cause or origin isn't known.  It cannot be explained.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See mysterious'.[j35] 'adjective mystery' Can you identify our mystery guest?  We went on a mystery tour.
example: The motive for the murder remains a mystery. [j33] Scientists are unlocking more and more of the mysteries of nature. [j33] It's a mystery to me why she ever married him

senses.definition: ' If something is described as mystic, it is concerned with secret spiritual matters.
example: The mystic ceremony filled the spectators with awe. [j33] The cover of the book was decorated with mystic symbols. [j33] She claimed to have attained a state of mystic enlightenment
' A mystic is someone who has great knowledge or understanding of spiritual matters
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun mysticism'

comment: verb forms mystifies, mysti~ fied, mystifying
definition: If something mystifies you, you find it puzzling and difficult to understand.
example: I was mystified by her sudden change of mind. [j33] Progamming the video mystifies me completely

senses.definition: ' A myth is also an imaginary thing or person or an invented idea.
example: Often it describes supernatural events and explains why things in the world are the way they are.  A similar word is legend
It turned out that his rich uncle was just a myth
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective mythical'
